resources.string: The Ishihara Test is used to assess the existence of color blindness. In other words, to evaluate if there is a color blindness disorder that affects color vision (such as green and red).
Color blindness is a vision dysfunction characterized by impaired color perception, which can range from confusion between certain shades of green and red, to no color distinction.
The Ishihara Test evaluates the congenital alteration of color vision, that is, color blindness. Most of these alterations are reduced to red-green deficiency.
- Try to make the lighting as similar as possible to natural light and avoid as many reflections as possible.
- You must hit the numbers in less than 3 seconds.
